descript.abstract:
The University of Oregon's (UO) Solar Radiation Monitoring Network consists of 38 monitoring stations in the Pacific Northwest (Idaho, Montana, Oregon, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming). The following parameters are monitored in near real time at most of the stations: total solar radiation (global horizontal radiation); direct normal irradiance (beam radiation); diffuse horizontal irradiance (diffuse sky radiation); ultraviolet radiation; barometric pressure; air temperature; rainfall; wind speed; wind direction; relative humidity; and solar cell performance. These monitoring stations can supply the engineering data needed for large-scale solar electric system designs and for improved groundtruthing of satellite solar radiation data.
A variety of types of data files can be downloaded for each site:
Cumulative summary files summarize single types of data for the entire period during which measurements have been taken. Daily total files have total solar radiation readings for each day during a given year. Monthly average files record averaged solar radiation over 5-, 10, 15, or 60-minute intervals for each month of a given year. Single element profile files display values of a single data type in a tabular format, where there is a column for each hour of the day, and a row for each day of the month. Archival files contain original and corrected short interval (5-, 10-, 15-, or 60-minute) data for each day during a given month. Each of these files typically contains a number of different solar radiation and meteorological data streams. Multifilter Rotating Shadowband Radiometer (MFR-7) files contain spectral and broadband global, diffuse, and beam measurements from an MFR. Average annual and monthly irradiance maps show the amount of solar radiation available in the Pacific Northwest. The UO Solar Radiation Monitoring Network complements and provides additional geographic coverage to the DOE Cooperative Networks For Renewable Resource Measurements (CONFRRM) Network, the NOAA SURFRAD Network, and the NOAA Integrated Surface Irradiance Study (ISIS) Network.

Data_Set_Link.Label: Cumulative Summary Files
Data_Set_Link.Link_Note: Cumulative summary data files provide hourly average and monthly average summaries of the data covering the entire period for which data has been analyzed. Each cumulative summary file contains data from only one type of measurement. Use this form to select cumulative summary files for downloading. Check appropriate stations, and then specify types of data that are of interest.

Data_Set_Link.Label: Daily Total Files
Data_Set_Link.Link_Note: These files contain daily totals of solar radiation measurements and daily averages of meteorological measurements, except rainfall, which is totaled. Each file covers one year of data. Use this form to select daily total files for downloading. Check appropriate stations, and then specify years of interest.

Data_Set_Link.Label: Monthly Average Data Files
Data_Set_Link.Link_Note: These files contain monthly averaged data over 5, 10, 15, or 60 minute intervals, for each month of a year. Use this form to select monthly average files for downloading. Check appropriate stations, and then specify the years and types of data that are of interest.

Data_Set_Link.Label: Single Element Profile Files
Data_Set_Link.Link_Note: These files present data in a tabular format that facilitates computation of daily totals and hourly average values. Use this form to select single element profile files for downloading. Check appropriate stations, and then specify the types of data and range of months that are of interest.

Data_Set_Link.Label: Archival Files
Data_Set_Link.Link_Note: Archival files contain processed and edited data. The file format is tab-separated ASCII, so data may easily be imported into a spreadsheet program. Currently, these short interval files are in month blocks, with the data from the first time interval in the month occurring on the first (non-header) data line. Time intervals are consistent within a given file. Intervals occurring in our archival data files are: 5, 10, 15, or 60 minutes long. Use this form to select archival files for downloading. Check appropriate stations, and then specify a range of months that are of interest.

Data_Set_Link.Label: Parsed TMY2 Files
Data_Set_Link.Link_Note: These Typical Meteorological Year 2 (TMY2) data files are one year of values from each of the 239 sites in the National Solar Radiation Data Base (NSRDB) that represent the typical solar radiation and meteorological conditions as determined from the 30-year (1961-1990) database. Use this form to select parsed TMY2 data files for downloading.

Data_Set_Link.Label: Multifilter Rotating Shadowband Radiometer (MFR-7) Files
Data_Set_Link.Link_Note: These files contain global, diffuse, and direct normal beam measurements from one broadband sensor and six narrow band sensors. Use this form to select MFR-7 files for downloading.

Data_Set_Link.Label: Northwest Solar Resource Maps
Data_Set_Link.Link_Note: These average annual and monthly irradiance maps show the amount of solar radiation available in the Pacific Northwest.
